claims.claim: The study uses JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy to test whether TRAPPIST-1 b is airless or has an atmosphere.

evidence.quote: Instrument: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve.
Inference workflow: retrieval models comparing atmosphere-free and atmosphere-bearing scenarios.

claims.caveat: The report is a structured summary, so full observational details, calibrations, and priors are not provided.

claims.claim: Evidence was gathered from both thermal redistribution behavior and a CO2-sensitive spectral feature near 15 micrometers.

evidence.quote: Thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.
15 um CO2 spectral band depth estimate | 96 ppm | Flat-spectrum null | Spectral structure is consistent with atmospheric absorption

claims.caveat: The exact signal significance depends on retrieval assumptions and remaining instrumental or model limitations.

claims.claim: A strict no-atmosphere interpretation is disfavored because it cannot fit all observables at once.

evidence.quote: A pure no-atmosphere model cannot simultaneously match both phase amplitude and spectral band behavior.
Heat transport efficiency (epsilon) | 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14) | 0.0 for perfect no-atmosphere limit

claims.caveat: Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions may alter how strongly this disfavoring is interpreted.

claims.claim: Atmospheric composition and pressure remain uncertain; O2-rich cases are still viable under current data constraints.

evidence.quote: O2-rich atmosphere cases are not fully ruled out by current data.
Preferred pressure scale in CO2-rich retrieval family | 0.3-1.0 bar | Near-vacuum branch
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.

claims.caveat: The null and alternative models are constrained by limited wavelength coverage and finite signal-to-noise in current observations.
